skill.name: brenda-database
skill.description: Access BRENDA enzyme database via SOAP API. Retrieve kinetic parameters (Km, kcat), reaction equations, organism data, and substrate-specific enzyme information for biochemical research and metabolic pathway analysis.
skill.summary: Access BRENDA enzyme database via SOAP API. Retrieve kinetic parameters (Km, kcat), reaction equatio...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate scientific tool for querying the BRENDA enzyme database. Static findings are false positives caused by the analyzer misidentifying code examples as shell commands, biochemical abbreviations as C2 keywords, and proper credential handling as sensitive data access. All network requests go to the official BRENDA API. No evidence of malicious intent, data exfiltration, or command-and-control behavior.

content.user_title: Query enzyme data from BRENDA database
content.value_statement: Access comprehensive enzyme kinetic data from the world's largest enzyme database. Find Km values, reaction equations, organism-specific parameters, and substrate specificity data for biochemical research and metabolic engineering.
actual_capabilities: Retrieve Michaelis constant (Km) and kcat values for any enzyme by EC number
Get reaction equations, substrates, and products for enzymatic reactions
Compare enzyme properties across different organisms
Find optimal pH, temperature, and cofactor requirements for enzymes
Export kinetic data to CSV or JSON formats
limitations: Requires BRENDA account and API credentials for access
Rate limited to approximately 1 request per second
Only includes enzyme data from the official BRENDA SOAP API
Does not include protein sequence or structure data

use_cases.title: Enzyme kinetic analysis
use_cases.description: Retrieve Km and kcat values to characterize enzyme behavior and compare across organisms.

use_cases.title: Pathway design
use_cases.description: Find enzymes for specific reactions and optimize conditions for metabolic pathway construction.

use_cases.title: Literature data extraction
use_cases.description: Extract enzyme parameters from published BRENDA data for computational modeling and analysis.

prompt_templates.title: Basic query
prompt_templates.prompt: Get Km values for alcohol dehydrogenase (EC 1.1.1.1) from BRENDA.

prompt_templates.title: Organism filter
prompt_templates.prompt: Find Km values for EC 1.1.1.1 in Escherichia coli and Homo sapiens.

prompt_templates.title: Reaction search
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all reactions involving glucose and their enzyme EC numbers.

prompt_templates.title: Pathway builder
prompt_templates.description: Find the enzymatic pathway to produce lactate from pyruvate including all required cofactors.

output_examples.input: Get Km values for alcohol dehydrogenase (EC 1.1.1.1) for human and yeast
output: Cofactors: NAD+ required for both organisms

best_practices: Store BRENDA credentials in environment variables for secure authentication
Add rate limiting delays (0.5-1 second) between API calls to avoid rate limits
Use specific EC numbers and organism filters to reduce data volume and improve response times
anti_patterns: Making concurrent API requests without delays will trigger rate limiting
Using wildcards for broad searches without limiting results can return massive datasets
Not caching results for repeated queries wastes API quota and slows performance

faq.question: Do I need a BRENDA account?
faq.answer: Yes, you must register at brenda-enzymes.org to get API credentials.

faq.question: What is an EC number?
faq.answer: Enzyme Commission numbers classify enzymes (e.g., 1.1.1.1 for alcohol dehydrogenase).

faq.question: What does Km represent?
faq.answer: The Michaelis constant - the substrate concentration at half-maximal reaction velocity.

faq.question: How many requests can I make?
faq.answer: BRENDA recommends 1 request per second for sustained usage.

faq.question: What data formats are supported?
faq.answer: Export to CSV, JSON, or Excel formats for downstream analysis.

faq.question: Can I search by organism?
faq.answer: Yes, filter queries by organism name for species-specific enzyme data.
